title: Stephen Lynch (politician)
deleted: {{See also|2001 Massachusetts's 9th congressional district special election}}

Lynch announced his candidacy for the 9th district seat in 2001, when longtime incumbent U.S. Representative [[Joe Moakley]], stricken with [[leukemia]], decided not to seek a 17th term. This was a departure from Lynch's previous plan to run for [[Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts|lieutenant governor of Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/73018335.html?FMT=ABS|title=Prospective candidates walk a fine line on Moakley seat|work=The Boston Globe|date=May 15, 2001|last=Johnson|first=Glen}}</ref> Moakley died in May 2001, before his term ended, and Lynch announced a run for the special election to succeed him.<ref name="globe-2001" /> The early front-runner in the race was lawyer [[Max Kennedy]], son of Democratic U.S. Senator [[Robert F. Kennedy]]. Political missteps dragged Kennedy down in the polls, and his abrupt departure in June 2001 put Lynch in the lead.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/06/12/us/max-kennedy-citing-family-pulls-out-of-race-for-house.html|title=Max Kennedy, citing family, pulls out of race for House|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 12, 2001|last=Goldberg|first=Carey}}</ref> The remaining candidates included eight Democrats and two Republicans, all with similar political positions; according to ''The Boston Globe'', the candidates "struggled to find areas of conflict" when debating.<ref name="globe-defends">{{cite news|title=Lynch defends work as lawyer|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/78361051.html?FMT=ABS|first=Benjamin|last=Gedan|date=August 21, 2001|work=The Boston Globe}}</ref>

In the September Democratic primary, Lynch's main opponents were state Senators [[Cheryl Jacques]], [[Brian A. Joyce]] and [[Marc R. Pacheco]]. During the campaign, Lynch faced criticism as his past improprieties were uncovered, including two arrests, defaulting on student loans, and a history of tax delinquency.<ref name="globe-2001">{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/84634139.html?FMT=ABS|title=Lynch cruises to Congress in 9th district|work=The Boston Globe|date=October 17, 2001|last=Mooney|first=Brian C.}}</ref> Gay rights advocates attacked him for "a history of supporting anti-gay legislation."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/06/24/us/political-briefing-boston-gays-blast-democrat-hopeful.html|title=Political Briefing – Boston Gays Blast Democrat Hopeful|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 24, 2001|last=Ayres|first=B. Drummond, Jr.}}</ref> Still, Lynch maintained strong local support going into the primary.<ref name="globe-2001" /> As he pulled ahead in polls and fundraising, Jacques and Joyce attacked his 1994 racial violence case and subsequent positions on hate crime as evidence that he was not supportive of civil rights.<ref name="herald-jacques" /><ref name="cq-2004" /><ref name="globe-defends" />

On September 11, 2001, Lynch won the Democratic primary with 39% of the vote to Jacques's 29%.<ref>{{cite web |work=Our Campaigns |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=94701 |title=MA District 9 - Special D Primary}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F04EFD81338F930A2575AC0A9679C8B63|title=Conservative Democrat Wins Primary in Boston|work=The New York Times|date=September 13, 2001}}</ref> The same day, the [[September 11 attacks]] took place, which dampened the ensuing general election race between Lynch and the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee, state Senator [[Jo Ann Sprague]]. As both sides turned to similar themes of patriotism and defense, Lynch benefited from his district's . On October 16, he defeated Sprague, 65%-33%.<ref name="globe-2001" /><ref>{{cite web |work=Our Campaigns |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=746 |title=MA District 9 - Special Election}}</ref>

Lynch was sworn into the [[107th United States Congress|107th Congress]] on October 23, 2001. The ceremony had been delayed for a weekend, as the [[2001 anthrax attacks]] had led to a shutdown of Congressional office buildings. In a press conference after his swearing-in, Lynch remarked on the unlikelihood of his career path, comparing himself to [[The Beverly Hillbillies#Characters|Jed Clampett]] of ''[[The Beverly Hillbillies]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lynch joins a Congress in crisis mode; newest Democrat, of South Boston, finds office closed|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/85661261.html?FMT=ABS|work=The Boston Globe|last=Johnson|first=Glen|date=October 24, 2001}}</ref>

title: Stephen Lynch (politician)
deleted: Lynch was reelected unopposed in 2002, 2004, and 2008. In 2006, Republican perennial candidate [[Jack E. Robinson III]] decided to challenge Lynch and lost, 78%–22%.<ref>{{cite web |work=Our Campaigns |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=206955 |title=MA – District 09}}</ref> After Lynch voted against the [[Affordable Care Act]], Mac D'Alessandro, a first-time candidate for office, challenged him in the [[2010 United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts#District 9|2010 Democratic primary]]. D'Alessandro was the New England political director for the [[Service Employees International Union]] (SEIU), which spent almost $300,000 on direct mail and other support for him. ''The Boston Globe'' also endorsed D'Alessandro. In September, Lynch defeated him 65%–35%.<ref>{{cite web |work=Our Campaigns |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=618713 |title=MA District 9 - D Primary}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/house-races/118821-rep-lynch-survives-healthcare-vote-primary- |title=Rep. Lynch survives healthcare-vote primary|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=September 14, 2010|last=Miller|first=Sean J.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Boston Globe|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/editorials/articles/2010/09/06/dalessandro_for_democrats_a_chance_for_a_new_voice|title=D'Alessandro for Democrats; a chance for a new voice|newspaper=Boston Globe|date=September 6, 2010}}</ref> In November, he defeated Republican Vernon Harrison and Independent Candidate Phil Dunkelbarger.<ref>{{cite web |work=Our Campaigns |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=490783 |title=MA – District 09}}</ref> After redistricting, Lynch decided to run in the newly redrawn {{ushr|MA|8}} in the [[2012 United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts#District 9|2012 election]]. His new district includes the city of [[Quincy, Massachusetts|Quincy]] and some other towns on the South Shore. In November, he defeated Republican Joe Selvaggi, 76%–24%.<ref>{{cite web |work=Our Campaigns |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=705052 |title=MA – District 08}}</ref>
